I find myself looking for solutions that acknowledge everyone's legitimate needs instead of just picking sides. What if there were programs that helped small landlords cover costs when they work with struggling tenants? What if we had better rapid rehousing assistance so eviction wasn't such a devastating outcome? What if we actually built enough affordable housing so people weren't competing for scraps?

The more I think about it, the more I realize that a lot of our housing debates are really about rationing scarcity rather than addressing it. We're arguing over who gets hurt by the shortage instead of asking why the shortage exists in the first place.

It's made me more skeptical of simple solutions in general, honestly. When someone proposes a policy that sounds like it only helps one side, I find myself asking "okay, but what about the other people affected by this?" Not because I don't care about tenants or think landlords deserve special treatment, but because I've seen what happens when good people get caught in the middle of poorly designed systems.

I guess I'm more interested in solutions that recognize the humanity on all sides now, rather than ones that require someone to be the villain.

<END>
